titleStmt.title: A most delightful history of the famous clothier of England, called, Jack of Newbery, in the days of King Henry the Eight; how he was beloved of his mistris above all her wealtheir sutors : what great and valiant things he did for England : and the great number of poor he daily cherished. And how (when the King sent for him) he refused (with his company) to leave the hill of ants to go to the king : and therefore the king went to him which he wittily excused with many other very pleasant passages / written by W.S.

titleStmt.title: A most delightful history of the famous clothier of England, called, Jack of Newbery, in the days of King Henry the Eight; how he was beloved of his mistris above all her wealtheir sutors : what great and valiant things he did for England : and the great number of poor he daily cherished. And how (when the King sent for him) he refused (with his company) to leave the hill of ants to go to the king : and therefore the king went to him which he wittily excused with many other very pleasant passages / written by W.S.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A mo≈øt Delightful HISTORY Of the Famous Clothier of England, CALLED, JACK of NEWBERY, In the days of King Henry the Eighth; how he was beloved of his Mi≈øtris above all her Wealthier Sutors: what great and valiant things he did for England: and the great number of poor he daily cheri≈øhed.

And how (when the King ≈øent for him) he refu≈øed (with his company) to leave the Hill of Ants to go to the King: and therefore the King went to him: which he wittily excu≈øed: with many other very plea≈øant pa≈ø≈øages.
Written by W. ‚Ä¢ . F. C.
Printed for W. Thackeray, at the Sign of the Angel in Duck-Lane.

div.head: THE MOST Delightful Hi≈øtory OF Jack of Newberry.
div.p: IN the Reign of King Henry the Eighth, one John Winchcomb, being an Apprentice to a rich Clothier in the town of Newberry in Bark≈øhire, a pretty hand≈øome Youth, his Ma≈øter dyed, and left his Mi≈øtris a Widdow; who perceiving Jack to be a faithful, careful, and tru≈øty Servant, ≈øhe put him in great tru≈øt in the Hou≈øe; who as carefully performed the tru≈øt repo≈øed in him.

His Mi≈øtris having many Suitors coming to her, could not fancy any: for her Man John had ≈øtoln away her heart. The Par≈øon of Spinhome-land woo'd her, and often ≈øolicited with her to make her his Wife, but could not obtain her love, becau≈øe he was a Clergy-man; too much (≈øhe thought) devoted to his Study. A rich Tanner was a ≈øecond Wooer, but could not ≈øpeed; for
though he was rich, yet was he too Old for hee young and lu≈øty de≈øires. A Taylor was a third man, who was almo≈øt confident of her love; but all in vain, for her man John, oh! he was the man that had ≈øo wounded her heart that ≈øhe could love no other man.

She ≈øeeing the backwardne≈øs of John, her man (after many occa≈øions which ≈øhe gave him to wooe her) came at la≈øt, and told him plainly that ≈øhe loved him, which ≈øecret ≈øhe did earne≈øtly de≈øire him not to impart to any: but he very mode≈øtly blu≈øhing with a Ro≈øie colour in his Cheeks, not knowing low to expre≈øs him≈øelf ‚Ä¢ s he de≈øired, being a≈øtoni≈øhed hereat, an≈øwered: Sweet Mi≈øtris (quoth he) I am but a Child to undertake ≈øo great a thing, it is a charge, the di≈øcharge whereof methinks I fear to undertake: At which an≈øwer, ≈øhe was ≈øomething di ‚Ä¢ couraged in her ≈øute for the pre≈øent, and ki≈ø≈øing of him, brake off di≈øcour≈øe for that time; and night approaching, ≈øhe went to Bed, but took but little re≈øt; but either ≈ølumbering (at the be≈øt) or Dreaming of her pretty Man John. She was ≈øo troubled, as if ≈øhe had been wounded in a Pri≈øon, and with many Cogitations of her Beloved, fetched many deep ≈øighs in that dole≈øom and dark
night: thinking it long e're morning came, rejoycing to ≈øee the light appear; more to embrace her dear Servant, or rather her Ma≈øter, John.

She going to ≈øee Bartholomew Fair, as Women u≈øe to do, to ≈øee and be ≈øeen, took her man John with her; who whil≈øt ≈øhe was talking with a friend, e≈øpyed him ≈øaluting a pretty Maid, which made her own mouth water; and biting her Lips, ≈øhe left di≈øcour≈øing with her Neighbor to go to John, to prevent his further familiarity with the Maid.

Afterwards ≈øhe met with the Taylor her Sweet-heart, ≈øo neat as could be, in the Fair; who de≈øiring her to drink a Cup of Wine with him, was denied again and again, but by importunity ≈øhe was per≈øwaded; and he e≈øpying the Tanner, called him into t ‚Ä¢ e Tavern to them, to help to bear their Charges; little imagining that he was a Sutor to the ≈øame Widdow; and both of them e≈øpying the Par≈øon go by, called him in, expecti ‚Ä¢ g to make him their Solliciter; thus were they all meerly drawn into Cupid's Paradice: but when each had di≈øcovered their intents to other, they were all exceedingly perplexed, not knowing how this Divi≈øion might be ended: At la≈øt, it was de≈øired of the
Widdow which of them ≈øhe loved be≈øt: and ≈øhe an≈øwered, that ≈øhe loved them all; and gave them thanks for their charges; but (quoth the Par≈øon) can you find in your heart to Marry me? It is your Office to Marry, quoth ≈øhe, and not mine. Then (quoth the Tanner) will you make me your Husband? Truly Neighbour, quoth ≈øhe, methinks you might better be my Father, you are of great Years to Marry ≈øuch a young Widdow as I am. Then (quoth the Taylor) Widdow, i ‚Ä¢ is I that mu≈øt enjoy you; ≈øhall you and I be Marryed? Yes, I hope ≈øo (quoth the Widdow) when we and our ≈øweet-hearts are agreed: So de≈øi ‚Ä¢ ing to take her leave of them, giving them t ‚Ä¢ anks for their co≈øts they ≈øpent on her, ≈øhe aro≈øe up to go away; but they de≈øiring a full an≈øwer from her, de≈øired her to give them better ≈øatisfaction to their Reque≈øts. If (quoth ≈øhe) you will come to my Hou ‚Ä¢ e on Thur≈øday, I will give you full ≈øatisfaction: at which time they all came; and ≈øhe told them all then plainly, that ≈øhe would marry none of them, for ≈øhe had one nearer home, whom ≈øhe loved ≈øo well, that ≈øhe could not marry any other man; ≈øo they went all away very ≈øad and di≈øcontented.

Night approaching, ≈øhe talked privately
with her Man John, wooing him to marry her; which he ≈øtill through ba≈øhfulne≈øs refu≈øed: And when night approached, ≈øhe cau≈øed a ≈øpecial bed to be made for her man John to lie in; which bed was onely for ≈øpecial ≈øtrangers to lie in, or for her Husband when he was not well: and ≈øhe lay her ≈øelf in the next Chamber to him, which ≈øhe locked up, and kept the Key thereof her ≈øelf.

But when ≈øhe had lain in Bed an hour or two, ≈øhe began to think it very long to lye alone; ≈øo ≈øhe aro≈øe out of her bed, and went to her man John, ≈øhivering and ≈øhaking, and lifting up his bed cloaths, he ≈øtarted; Who is there, quoth he? It is I my ≈øweet John, quoth ≈øhe, I am your Mi≈øtri≈øs; it is an extream cold Night, and I, lying alone, am almo≈øt ≈øtarved in my Bed: Good John, afford me the favour of one Nights lodging by thy ≈øide, my John, I pray thee. Alas poor Mi≈øtri≈øs, quoth he, come, come lye clo≈øe: Yea, yea, quoth ≈øhe, O ≈øweet and good John; but here I leave them till the next morning.

She got up very early in the morning, and calling for John her man to go abroad with her, ≈øhe took him to the Church of Saint Bartholomews;
and calling for the Pr≈øe≈øt of the place, ≈øhe, with him, per≈øwaded John that they might then be married together; which with ≈ømall intreaty he was per≈øwaded to, and ≈øo they returned home; and when they went to dinner, ≈øhe made him to ≈øit in her old husbands Chair by her ≈øelf at the end of the Table, at which his old fellow ≈øervants began to ≈ømile; and before Dinner was ended, ≈øhe took him about the neck and ki≈ø≈øed him, and told her Servants that he was her Husband, and commanded them to give him the re≈øpects due to a Ma≈øter.

He al≈øo ≈øpake lovingly to them, and told them, that he would not forget that he was once their Fellow-Servant, but would de≈øerve their re≈øpects to the uttermo≈øt of his indeavour. Thus they ≈øpent the day in loving Toyings, only ≈øome over-≈øight of the Work-men withal, and at night they went to Bed.

This new married Bride was the next morning vi≈øited by divers Go≈ø≈øips of her acqu ‚Ä¢ intance, that heard of the Wedding, who ≈øpent each of them their verdict, what the event of this her ha≈øty Match would be; which Go≈ø≈øips did exceedingly di≈øcourage her‚ñ™ Oh! but (quoth ≈øhe) I w ‚Ä¢ ll take an Order
for that, for I will curb him at the fir≈øt, that I will make ≈øure that he ≈øhall never crow over me, I warrant you.

And indeed ≈øhe began to grow as great a Go≈ø≈øip as any was in Newberry, and would ≈øometimes come home very late at night; in≈øomuch, that at la≈øt her Husband John went to bed, and locked her out, and took the Key up into his own Chamber; and when the good wife ≈øaw that ≈øhe was ≈øhut out of doors, ≈øhe knocked very hard, till at la≈øt her Husband looked out at the window, and bad her to go look her lodging at night, where ≈øhe had been ≈øitting all day: Such Go≈ø≈øips (quoth he) as you, the Cage is the fitte≈øt Lodging for, go to the Con≈øtable, and be≈øpeak a bed of him.

Oh! dear Husband, quoth ≈øhe, be not ≈øo angry, I pray you; give me leave to come into my Bed, good ≈øweet Husband, I pray you, and let me not ≈øtand thus in the cold, le≈øt I lo≈øe my life thereby: After many fine words wherewith ≈øhe had intreated her Husband to come down and open the door, he came down to her, and let her in; to whom ≈øhe di≈ø≈øemblingly pretended to have lo≈øt her Wedding-Ring from off her hand, who lovingly going forth with the Candle in his hand (in his ≈øhirt) looked up and down upon
the goound for it: and ≈øhe the mean time ≈øtepping in, clapped to the door, and ≈øhut him out; whereat he was much perplexed, and knocked a long time in the cold before ≈øhe would an≈øwer, who at la≈øt opening the Window, bad him go look a Lodging with him Con≈øtables Wife; and asked him whether he thought it good to lye in the cold in the Street: Now (quoth ≈øhe) ≈øhe who was even now at your mercy, hath gotten you at hers. Oh ≈øweet Wife, quoth he, be not angry, but let me come in; I ≈øwear unto thee, that I will never ≈øhut thee forth of doors again, but thou ≈øhalt do what thou wilt and I will never meddle no make with you what≈øoever you do hereafter: whereupon ≈øhe came down and opened the door, and let him in; and there they made great prote≈øtations each to other, never to affront or fall out one with the other after; and with a good Sack-po≈ø≈øet the Covenant was agreed between them.

Shortly after the King was to rai≈øe an Army of Souldiers again≈øt the Scots, who was ri≈øen again≈øt the Engli≈øh; and Jack of Newberry rai≈øed at his own charges an hundred and fifty men, and allowed white Coats red Caps, and yellow Feathers; and led
them him≈øelf: fifty of them were valiant Hor≈øemen; fifty Pikes, and fifty Mu≈øquetiers; all brave Steeds, good Arms, and valiant men; who marching by before the Queen, Queen Katherine, ≈øhe called for him, and under≈øtanding what he was, after ≈øhe had put forth her hand for him to ki≈øs, ≈øhe promi≈øed to acquaint the King's Maje≈øty with his free and great ≈øervice.

div.head: A Song u≈øed by Jack of Newberry and his Souldiers:

lg.l: KIng Jamy of Scots had rai≈øed
But let him come, we'l thunder him back,
Jack of Newbery comes proud Scots take heed
Who for brave England will fight with you,

div.p: Shortly after Jack of Newberry heard that the King was to ride by Newberry, ≈øo he with his Servants went out into the field, and finding an Hill of Pi≈ømires, drew his Sword and guarded it; and the King coming by, ≈øent for him to know the rea≈øon why he guarded that place with his Sword drawn, the King in per≈øon being to pa≈øs by there? who returned an≈øwer, That he was bu≈øie, and could not ≈øpeak with him; and the King is on Hor≈øe-back, and I am on Foot, therefore (quoth he) he may the better come to me. Tell the King, that I ≈øtand here to guard the laborious Ants from their Enemies: which Me≈ø≈øage being brought to the King, he went to Jack of Newberry, expecting that it was done to make ≈øome je≈øt for his plea≈øure: and when the King came, Jack, with all his men, fell on their knees, and cryed, God ≈øave the King; your Sacred Maje≈øty (quoth he) hath vanqui≈øhed all mine Enemies. Now tru≈øt me, quoth the King, you are ≈øtout Souldiers to fight again≈øt Butterflies, and with≈øtand ≈øuch mighty Gyants.

My dread Soveraign, quoth Jack of Newberry, not long ago, in my conceit, I ≈øaw the mo≈øt provident Nation of the Ants, ≈øummoned
their chief Peers to a Parliament, which was held in the famous City of Drie-du≈øtie, the one and thirtieth day of September; whereas by their Wi≈ødoms I was cho≈øen their King; at what time al≈øo many Bills of complaint were brought in again≈øt divers ill Members in the Common-Wealth, among≈øt whom the Mole was attainted of High-trea≈øon to their State, and therefore was bani≈øhed for ever from their quiet Kingdom; ≈øo was the Gra≈øhopper and Catterpiller, becau≈øe they were not only idle, but al≈øo lived upon the labours of other Men: Among≈øt the re≈øt, the Butterflie was very much mi≈øliked, but few dur≈øt ≈øay any thing to him, becau≈øe of his Golden Apparel: who, through ≈øufference, grew ≈øo ambitious and malapart, that the poor Ant could no ≈øooner get an Egg into her Ne≈øt, but he would have it away, e≈øpecially again≈øt Ea≈øter which at length was mi≈øliked.

This painted A≈øs took ≈ønuff in the no≈øe, and a≈ø≈øembled a great many other of his own Coat, by windy Wars to root the≈øe painful people out of the Land, that he him≈øelf might be above them. The≈øe were proud Butterflies, quoth the King.

Whereupon, I, with my men, quoth Jack, prepared our ≈øelves to with≈øtand them, till ≈øuch
time as your Maje≈øties Royal pre≈øence put them to flight.

div.head: The Song which Jack Sung with his Men before the KING.

lg.l: I Have taken upon me a charge,
That they may walk at large,
And keep that which they have;
But now my King is here,
I bow down low my knee,
I, and my men, and mine,
my Ants, and all we have;

div.p:
Now to return again to Jack and his Wife, it fell out that ≈øhe fell ≈øick and dyed; and being buried, Jack fell in love with one of his Maids: and ≈øending for her Father, to know what he would give with his Daughter: he came to Newberry, and ≈øeeing the wealth of his Daughters Sweet-heart, and Ma≈øter, he was a≈øtoni≈øhed: for Jack had, viz.
In one Room two hundred Loom all going.
Two hundred Boys making Quills.
A hundred Women Carding.
Two hundred Maids in another Room Spinning.
An hundred and fifty Boys picking of Wool.
Fifty Siermen.
Eight Rowers.
Fourty Dyers in the Dye-hou≈øe.
Twenty men in a Fulling-Mill.
Ten fat Oxen he ≈øpent every week in his hou≈øe, be≈øides Butter, Chee≈øe, Fi≈øh, &c.
A Butcher for his own hou≈øe.
A Baker for his own hou≈øe.
A Brewer for his own hou≈øe.
Five Cooks.
Six Scullion-Boys.
Divers Turn-≈øpits, &c.

p.hi: Sir, (quoth the old man) I wis the zee you be bominable Rich, and cham content you ≈øhall have my Daughter, and God's Ble≈ø≈øing and mine light on you both. I vaith cham but a poor man, but I thong God cham of good exclamation among my Neighbours, and they will as zoon take my vice for any thing as a richer mans: thick I will be≈øtow you ≈øhall have with a very good will, becau≈øe che hear very good commendation of you in every place: therefore thick give you twenty Nobles, and a weaning Calf, and when I dye, and my Wife; you ≈øhall have the Revelation of my Goods

div.p: But Jack made more reckoning of the Woman's mode≈øty, and virtues, than of his Fathers proffer; and he married her, and made a great Wedding; and in≈øtead of receiving the old mans Dowrie, he gave him twenty pounds in money; be≈øides other good gifts.

Oh my good Zon! quoth the old man, Chri≈øts benizon be with thee evermore; For to tell thee true, we had zold all our
Kine to make money for my Daughters marriage, and this zeven year we ≈øhould not have been able to buy any more. Notwith≈øtanding we ≈øhould have zold all that ever we had, before my poor wench ≈øhould have lo≈øt her marriage: I ≈øhould have zold my Coat from my back, and my Bed from under me, before my Daughter ≈øhould have gone without you. I thank you good Father and Mother (quoth the Bride) and I pray God long to keeep you in health: then the Bride kneeling down, did her duty to her Parents; who weeping for very joy, departed.

Now there was one Randal Pert, a Draper, dwelling in Watling-≈øtreet, who owed to Jack of Newberry five hundred pounds; and it happend that Jack came up to London; and as he went to his Cu≈øtomers, he met in the ≈øtreet this Randal Pert in a Frock, carring a Porter's Basket, and an old ragged Doublet, and a torn pair of Breeches, with his Ho≈øe out at Heels, and a pair of old broken ≈ølip-≈øhooes on his feet, a Rope about his middle, and a grea≈øie Cap on his Head, and newly come out of Pri≈øon.

Now was his Wife, who before for daintine≈øs would not foul her fingers, nor turn her head a≈øide for fear of rumpling her Nemkinger,
yet now glad to go about and wa≈øh Bucks at the Thames ≈øide, and to be a chare-woman; her ≈øoft hand was now hardened with ≈øcouring, and in≈øtead of Gold Rings upon her Lilly white fingers, her hands and fingers were now filled with chaps.

But when her husband e≈øpyed Jack of Newberry his Creditor, he ran away as fa≈øt as he could, for fear of being arre≈øted: but he ≈øent h s man after him; who ≈øeeing one pur≈øue him, he ran the fa≈øter; and in running, here he lo≈øt one of his ≈ølip-≈øhooes, and there another, ever looking behind him with great fear: At la≈øt his Breeches being tyed but with one point, that with the ha≈øte he made, and the oldne≈øs thereof, brake, and his Breeches fell about his heels, and did ≈øo ≈øhackle him, that he fell down all along in the Street which his Ar≈øe bare, and an old ragged Shirt, he lay ≈øweating and blowing, being quite worn out of breath; to whom the fellow came, and brought him to his Ma≈øter, who took him to a Scrivener, to give him Bond for the payment of the money; and the time of the payment of the money was to be paid when the ≈øaid Pert was Sheriff of London, a thing very unlikely.

Well, the Scrivener made the Bond, to
be paid when Randal Pert was Sheriff of London, and thereunto ≈øet his hand for a Witne≈øs, and twenty per≈øons more that ≈øtood by.

And Jack of Newberry ≈øent for a new ≈øuit of Apparel for him out of Birchen-Lane, and a new Shirt, and Band, Hat, Ho≈øe, Shooes, and all things nece≈ø≈øary, Merchant-like; then he took for him a Shop in Canwick-≈øtreet, and furni≈øhed the ≈øame Shop with a thou≈øand pounds worth of Cloth, by which means, and other favours which he did for him, he grew in good credit again, and became very provident; and his Wife turned to be the be≈øt Hou≈øewife in the Pari≈øh; and he ≈øoon got good cu≈øtom, and was very provident, and increa≈øed in wealth, ≈øo that in ≈øhort time became one of the be≈øt men for wealth in the Pari≈øh; and there was ≈øo much notice taken of him, that he was cho≈øen Sheriff of London, and paid the five hundred pounds every penny; and kept a brave Hou≈øe in his Shrevalty, and afterwards being an Alderman of London, dyed before he came to be Lord Mayor, and left his Wife a gre ‚Ä¢ t E≈øtate.

Jack of Newberry, otherwi≈øe called Ma≈øter John Winchcomb, being grown very old, he fell ≈øick, and after few days he dyed; and
his Wife buried him in great Pomp: and he left his Wife a great E≈øtate, and many Legacies to Friends, and to many poor people were left by him; and to his Burial come the greate≈øt part of the Country all thereabouts, to ≈øee the good old man laid in his Grave, where we will leave him with this Epitaph.

div.head: EPITAPH.
div.l: OF Newberry here lies valiant Jack
≈øhrowded in white, come to his end
By Death that now hath broken his back,
who to his Country was a Frend;
An aid to tho≈øe that labour lov'd,
an help to poor, both blind and lame,
Men, Women, Children, all have prov'd
Winchcomb adieu, God hath thy Soul,
thy Body lies inclo≈øed in earth,
Thy Works brave Hi≈øtories do Enroul,
thy Life, thy Fame, ev'n from thy birth.

div.head: The≈øe Books following are to be Sold by William Thackeray, at the Angel in Duck-Lane, near We≈øt-Smithfield.

list.item: THe famous Hi≈øtory of the Gentle Craft.
